p.s: The first one is informative and appealing, as the author uses we (l. 3) to directly involve the readers, the second and the third paragraph are informative and the last one is appealing due to the same reason in paragraph one, and it is argumentative.

Argument used in the last paragraph are: ... you do not learn to stand on your own two feet if someone is holding you (ll. 18-19), Indulging differences can be harmful if it prevents communities from integrating (ll. 19-20), englishEnglish should be compulsory for all citizens (l. 21), public figures do not to speak up as they fear to be labelled as a racist but the not speaking up is even more harmful (ll. 22-23).
This specific text structure, results in the arguments being more memorable and effective.
Additionally the detailed description of the problems in Bangladeshi community leads to the reader gaining sympathy for those who suffer.
This does also support the effectiveness of the arguments.
Furthermore, the author often uses pronouns such as we and our (e.g. l. 4, 18).
As a consequence, the reader is directly involved in the events which raises the attention.
It also calls upon the readers to not against the problem as through the use of this, it is portrayed as it also is a problem for the reader.
His personal experience which is mentioned in the third paragraph gives the article an authentic personal note which could possibly help immigrants identify with Rahman.
In the second paragraph the author uses an anaphora (ll. 13-14).
The words this affects are My parents.
This marks the importance of the parents in this problems, as their displeasure to learn English or contrary to this their pleasure to learn englishEnglish projects onto the kid.
The shortenessshortness also contributes to the effectiveness of the article due to the increased noticeably.
The in the second paragraph installed metaphor, describes the inability of immigrated Bangladeshis to achieve educational development (l. 7).
It portrays the fatality of the circumstance through creating an image in the readersreader's mind.
The metaphor in the third paragraph compliments the other arguments (l. 18-19).
